screens.headline: Covered calls without owning stock?
screens.text: The Poor Man's Covered Call mimics covered calls using LEAPS instead of shares. Same income, 90% less capital.

screens.headline: PMCC = LEAP call + Sell short-term calls against it
screens.text: Buy a deep ITM LEAP call (long-term, .80+ delta) and sell short-term OTM calls against it, just like a covered call. But instead of owning 100 shares ($50,000), you own a LEAP ($5,000). You collect weekly/monthly premium while maintaining long exposure.

screens.headline: Renting out your mortgage property
screens.text: Covered call = You own a $50k house, rent it out for $500/month. PMCC = You have a mortgage on the house (only $5k down payment), rent it out for $500/month. Same rental income, way less capital tied up. If house appreciates, you still benefit. If it crashes below your mortgage, you lose the down payment.

reveal_sections.label: Traditional = Own house outright ($50k)
reveal_sections.content: Requires full capital to own 100 shares for covered calls.

reveal_sections.label: PMCC = Mortgage ($5k down)
reveal_sections.content: Use LEAP as stock replacement with fraction of capital.

reveal_sections.label: Same rent income, less capital
reveal_sections.content: Collect similar premium but free up $45k for other investments.

screens.question: What's the main advantage of PMCC over traditional covered calls?
options: Uses 80-90% less capital for same income
No need to manage the position
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly! Covered call requires $50,000 (100 shares). PMCC requires ~$5,000 (one LEAP). Both generate similar weekly/monthly income, but PMCC frees up $45,000 for other investments.
screens.explanation_wrong: Capital efficiency is the key. You can run 10 PMCC positions for the price of 1 covered call position, diversifying across stocks while generating 10x the income on same capital.

screens.question: Your PMCC: LEAP at $100 strike, short $120 call. Stock rallies to $125. What happens?
options: Short call gets assigned - close both legs or roll the short up
LEAP protects you from any loss
screens.explanation_correct: Right! If short call is assigned, you can either: A) Exercise your LEAP to deliver shares, or B) Close both legs (buy back short, sell LEAP) and take profit. Or C) Roll the short call to higher strike before assignment. Most traders roll.
screens.explanation_wrong: When short call goes ITM, you face assignment risk. But your LEAP protects you - you can exercise it to deliver shares. Most traders close both legs or roll the short call up and out to keep the position alive.

screens.headline: Build a PMCC
screens.description: MSFT at $400. Buy $360 LEAP (18 months, .82 delta) for $55. Sell $420 call (35 days, .28 delta) for $5. Net debit: $50 ($5,000). Track monthly income.

outputs.label: Month 1
outputs.value: Collect $5 ($500) | MSFT at $410 | Roll short, collect $6 more

outputs.label: Month 3
outputs.value: MSFT at $425 | Roll to $440 strike | Collect $4 | Continue monthly

outputs.label: Months 4-12
outputs.value: Average $4/month ($400) | Total income ~$5,500 | LEAP now worth ~$70 | Total profit: $7,500 (150% ROI)

outputs.label: vs Covered Call
outputs.value: Stock: $40,000 capital, $8,000 profit (20% ROI) | PMCC: $5,000 capital, $7,500 profit (150% ROI)

teaching_points: PMCC made 150% on $5k vs covered call 20% on $40k
Same total profit, but PMCC freed up $35k for other trades
Roll short calls monthly to continue collecting premium

cards.back: Buy LEAP (.80 delta, 12+ months) + Sell 30-45 day calls (.25-.35 delta) | Roll shorts every 21-30 days
LEAP: Deep ITM (stock price - 20%) | Short: OTM (stock price + 5-10%)
Bullish long-term + want income | Small account | Capital efficiency priority | Comfortable managing 2 legs
If stock drops below LEAP strike, consider closing | Roll shorts up if breached | Set stop loss at -50% on LEAP
Pros: 90% less capital, same income | Cons: Can lose 100% on LEAP, no dividends

screens.celebration_message: This is THE strategy for building wealth in small accounts!
